Sokolów Malopolski was home to several prominent rabbis and scholars in the 17th and 18th centuries, who attracted followers from across Poland and beyond. One of the most famous rabbis of this period was Rabbi Yitzhak Meir (also known as Yitzhak Meir Alter), who served as the rabbi of Sokolów Malopolski from 1802 until his death in 1866. Rabbi Yitzhak Meir was a renowned Talmudic scholar and religious leader who was known for his piety and his efforts to promote Torah study and observance.

Another prominent rabbi who lived in Sokolów Malopolski during this period was Rabbi Menachem Mendel Hager, who served as the town's rabbi from 1852 until his death in 1884. Rabbi Hager was the founder of the Vizhnitz Hasidic dynasty, which has followers around the world today. He was known for his charisma and his ability to connect with his followers, and he attracted a large following of devoted Hasidim.

Other prominent rabbis and scholars who lived in Sokolów Malopolski during this period included Rabbi Moshe ben Mordechai Yitzchak Shapira, who was the author of several important works of Jewish scholarship, and Rabbi Avraham Danzig, who was the author of the classic Jewish legal work, "Chayei Adam."

The followers of these rabbis and scholars were drawn to Sokolów Malopolski by the town's reputation as a center of Jewish learning and piety. They came from all over Poland and beyond to study Torah, observe Jewish customs and traditions, and seek the guidance of these great leaders. Despite the challenges and difficulties faced by the Jewish community in Sokolów Malopolski during this period, the town's rabbis and scholars played a significant role in preserving and transmitting Jewish knowledge and tradition to future generations.
